revision.comment: /* Intercontinental ballistic missiles */Typo fixing, replaced: the the → the (2) using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
{{Infobox military unit |unit_name= 320th Missile Squadron |image= [[File:LGM-30G Minuteman III test launch.jpg|250px]] |caption= LGM-30G Minuteman III test launch at Vandenburg AFB, California |dates=1942-1946; 1947–1948; 1951–1960; 1964–present |country={{flag|United States|23px}} |branch= {{air force|USA}} | type = Squadron | role = [[Intercontinental ballistic missile]] |size= |command_structure=[[Air Force Global Strike Command]] |current_commander= [[Lieutenant colonel (United States)|Lt Col]] Russell S. "Wheels" Williford |garrison= [[Francis E. Warren Air Force Base]] |ceremonial_chief= |colonel_of_the_regiment= |nickname=Moby Dick (World War II) |patron= |motto= |colors= |march= |mascot= |battles= [[Southwest Pacific Theater]] |notable_commanders= [[Lincoln D. Faurer]] |anniversaries= |decorations=[[Distinguished Unit Citation]]
[[Air Force Outstanding Unit Award]]
[[Philippine Presidential Unit Citation]] |battle_honours= |identification_symbol=[[Image:320th Missile Squadron.jpg|165px]] |identification_symbol_label=320th Missile Squadron emblem (approved 17 May 1965){{cite web |url= http://www.afhra.af.mil/factsheets/factsheet.asp?id=11965 |last1=Bailey|first1=Carl E.|title=Factsheet 320 Missile Squadron (AFGCS) [sic]|date=June 18, 2015|publisher=Air Force Historical Research Agency|deadurl=no |accessdate=May 16, 2016}} |identification_symbol_2=[[File:320th Strategic Reconnaissance Squadron - SAC - Emblem.png|165px]] |identification_symbol_2_label=Patch with unofficial 320th Strategic Reconnaissance Squadron emblem''See'' Maurer, ''Combat Squadrons'', p. 392 (no approved emblem) |identification_symbol_3=[[File:320th Bomb Sq emblem.png|165px]] |identification_symbol_3_label=320th Bombardment Squadron emblem (approved 27 March 1943)Watkins, pp. 86-87 |identification_symbol_4=[[File:320th Bombardment Squadron - Emblem.png|150px]] |identification_symbol_4_label=320th Bombardment Squadron "Jolly Rogers" patchThe 90th Bombardment Group "Jolly Rogers" emblem was used as a squadron patch and as a tail marking on B-24s with each squadron having its own color in the background. Watkins, pp. 86-87 }} The '''320th Missile Squadron''' is a [[United States Air Force]] unit. It is assigned to the [[90th Operations Group]], stationed at [[F.E. Warren AFB]], Wyoming. The 320 MS is equipped with the [[LGM-30G Minuteman III]] [[Intercontinental ballistic missile]] (ICBM), with a mission of nuclear deterrence. ==History== ===World War II=== {{Commons category-inline|90th Bombardment Group (United States Army Air Forces)|90th Bombardment Group}} The [[squadron (aviation)|squadron]] was first organized as the '''320th Bombardment Squadron''' at [[Key Field]], Mississippi in April 1942 as a [[Consolidated B-24 Liberator]] unit and one of the original squadrons of the [[90th Bombardment Group]]. The squadron trained with Liberators in the southeastern United States under [[III Bomber Command]] until August.{{cite web |url= http://www.afhra.af.mil/factsheets/factsheet.asp?id=9836 |last1=Robertson|first1=Patsy|title=Factsheet 90 Operations Group (AFSPC)|date=May 27, 2010|publisher=Air Force Historical Research Agency|deadurl=no |accessdate=May 11, 2016}} [[File:90th Bomb Group B-24s - 1943.jpg|thumb|left|"Jolly Rogers" of the 90th Bombardment Group on a mission, 1943]] [[File:90th Bomb Group B-24J 1944.jpg|thumb|left|B-24J with the distinct nose turret, probably in 1944.]] The squadron moved to [[Willow Run Airport]], Michigan for conversion training on newly manufactured Ford Liberators. Assigned to [[VII Bomber Command]] with B-24Ds, the unit moved to [[Hickam Field]], Hawaii in September. The squadron arrived in northern [[Queensland]], Australia in November 1942 and began bombardment missions under [[V Bomber Command]] almost immediately. The squadron attacked enemy [[airfield]]s, troop concentrations, ground installations and shipping in New Guinea, the [[Bismarck Archipelago]], [[Palau]] and the southern Philippines. The 3209th was awarded a [[Distinguished Unit Citation]] for its operations in Papua through January 1943. The unit participated in the [[Battle of Bismarck Sea]] in March 1943, and earned another citation for strikes on enemy airfields at [[Wewak]], New Guinea in September 1943 despite heavy [[flak]] and [[fighter Aircraft|fighter]] opposition. During 1944, the 320th supported the New Guinea Campaign through the end of June, then made long-range raids on oil refineries at [[Balikpapan]], Borneo, in September and October. In January 1945, the squadron moved to the Philippines and supported ground forces on [[Luzon]], attacked industrial targets on [[Formosa]], and bombed railways, airfields, and harbor facilities on the Asiatic mainland. Shortly before the end of the war in the Pacific, the 90th moved to [[Okinawa]], from which it would be able to strike the Japanese home islands. After [[VJ Day]], the squadron flew [[aerial reconnaissance|reconnaissance]] missions over Japan and ferried Allied prisoners of war from [[Okinawa]] to [[Manila]]. It ceased operations by November 1945. The squadron was inactivated in the Philippines in early 1946. ===Superfortress operations=== {{Main|90th Bombardment Wing}} The squadron was reactivated in July 1947 as a very heavy unit at [[Andrews Field]], Maryland. It was a component of one of seven bombardment groups activated at Andrews by [[Strategic Air Command]] (SAC) that day. Most of these units, including the 320th, were inactivated by September 1948 and it does not appear they were manned during this period.Mueller, p. 8Maurer, ''Combat Units'', pp. 102, 176, 178 [[File:90th Bombardment Wing Boeing B-29-100-BW Superfortress 45-21846 1948.jpg|thumb|Wing Boeing B-29Aircraft is Boeing B-29-100-BW Superfortress serial 45-21846]] The squadron was again organized at [[Fairchild Air Force Base]], Washington in January 1951 and equipped with the [[Boeing B-29 Superfortress]]. In February, as part of a reorganization of [[Strategic Air Command]] wings, the 90th Bombardment Group was reduced to paper status and the squadron was attached to the wing for operational control. In June 1952, this organization, which was designed to permit the wing commander to focus on the wing's combat units and the maintenance necessary to support combat aircraft, was formalized as the Dual Deputy Organization and the squadron was assigned to the wing.{{cite web |url= http://www.afhra.af.mil/factsheets/factsheet.asp?id=14782 |last1=Robertson|first1=Patsy|title=Factsheet 90 Missile Wing (AFGSC)|date=April 6, 2012|publisher=Air Force Historical Research Agency|deadurl=no |accessdate=May 8, 2016}}Deaile, pp. 175–176 In March 1951, the squadron moved to [[Forbes Air Force Base]], where it served primarily as a training unit. In May, it began serving as an Operational Training Unit for B-29 [[aircrew]]s and mechanics of newly-activating units. The squadron help organize and train the [[376th Bombardment Wing|376th]], [[308th Bombardment Wing|308th]], and [[310th Bombardment Wing]]s.Ravenstein, pp. 200–202{{cite web|url= http://www.afhra.af.mil/factsheets/factsheet.asp?id=9893 |last1=Robertson|first1=Patsy|title=Factsheet 308 Armament Systems Wing (AFMC)|date=August 27, 2015|publisher=Air Force Historical Research Agency|deadurl=no |accessdate=May 8, 2016}}{{cite web |url= http://www.afhra.af.mil/factsheets/factsheet.asp?id=17678 |last1=Kane|first1=Robert B.|title=Factsheet 310 Space Wing (AFRC)|date=December 23, 2010|publisher=Air Force Historical Research Agency|deadurl=no |accessdate=May 9, 2016}} In June, the squadron added duty as a Replacement Training Unit, primarily providing individual training for aircrew being assigned to existing [[Far East Air Forces]] B-29 units during the [[Korean War]].{{cite web |url= http://www.airforcehistoryindex.org/data/000/452/106.xml |last1=|first1=|title=Abstract, History 90 Bombardment Wing|date=1 October 1951|publisher=Air Force History Index|deadurl=no |accessdate=May 9, 2016}}Replacement Training Units trained individuals to fill positions in existing units. ''See'' Goss, p. xxxvi In November of 1952 it also began training replacement crews for the RB-29 [[aerial reconnaissance|reconnaissance]] model of the Superfortress and [[SHORAN]] personnel for [[Strategic Air Command]] (SAC). These training activities continued through November 1953. ===Strategic reconnaissance=== [[File:B-47-kc-97.jpg|thumb|B-47 and KC-97 as flown by the wing]] The squadron began to fly strategic reconnaissance missions in September 1953. The following year, it replaced its RB-29s with the jet [[Boeing RB-47 Stratojet]], with the first B-47E arriving on 25 June, although crews had begun training in March.90th Missile Wing Heritage Pamphlet, pp. 3, 15 One year later, the squadron and the entire 90th Strategic Reconnaissance Wing deployed as a unit to [[Eielson Air Force Base]], Alaska from 5 May until 31 August 1955, where the wing performed the final mapping of Alaska.90th Missile Wing Heritage Pamphlet, p. 15 In May 1958, the 90th Wing returned to the training mission serving as a combat crew training wing for RB-47 aircrews until it was inactivated on 20 June 1960. The squadron's personnel and equipment were transferred to the [[44th Bombardment Squadron]], which moved to Forbes on paper from [[Schilling Air Force Base]], Kansas the same day.Ravenstein, p. 68 ===Intercontinental ballistic missiles=== [[File:320th Missile Squadron - ALL.png|thumb|200px|LGM-30 Minuteman Missile Alert and Launch Facilities]] {{Commons category-inline|90th Missile Wing (United States Air Force)|90th Missile Wing}} The squadron was reactivated on 8 January 1964 as an [[intercontinental ballistic missile]] squadron assigned to the [[90th Strategic Missile Wing]] at [[Francis E. Warren Air Force Base]], Wyoming, and equipped with fifty [[LGM-30B Minuteman I]]s, armed with a single reentry vehicle. The squadron was the second of the 90th Wing's four Minuteman squadrons to activate, as construction on launch facitlities continued until the middle of 1964. Beginning in June 1973, its Minuteman I missiles began to be replaced by [[LGM-30G Minuteman III]]s, which could carry up to three reentry vehicles.{{cite web |url= http://www.afhra.af.mil/factsheets/factsheet.asp?id=14782 |last1=Robertson|first1=Patsy|title=Factsheet 90 Missile Wing (AFGSC)|date=April 6, 2012|publisher=Air Force Historical Research Agency|deadurl=no |accessdate=May 8, 2016}}{{cite web |url= http://www.warren.af.mil/AboutUs/FactSheets/Display/tabid/3813/Article/331279/90-mw-fact-sheet.aspx |last1=|first1=|title=90 MW Fact Sheet|date=August 19, 2010|publisher=90th Missile Wing Public Affairs|deadurl=no |accessdate=May 8, 2016}} In 2001 in compliance with the [[START I|Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty]], these missiles were limited to a single reentry vehicle In 1997 the squadron won the [[William H. Blanchard|Blanchard Trophy]] as the best missile operations squadron at the [[Guardian Challenge]] missile competition. It also received awards that year for the best missile maintenance team and the best missile crew.90th Missile Wing Heritage Pamphlet, p. 20The Blanchard Trophy was awarded at the squadron level for only a few years. For most of its existence it was awarded at the wing level. The 90th Wing has also won this award. 90th Missile Wing Heritage Pamphlet, p. 26 In more recent competitions, the squadron won the [[Samuel C. Phillips|Samuel C. Phillips Award]] as the best missile squadron in [[Air Force Space Command]] in 2005. It was awarded the [[Thomas H. Neary|Neary Trophy]] and the [[Robert E. Linhard|Linhard Trophy]] for best USAF missile crew in 2012.90th Missile Wing Heritage Pamphlet, pp. 23, 26 ==Lineage== * Constituted as the '''320 Bombardment Squadron''' (Heavy) on 28 January 1942 : Activated on 15 April 1942 : Redesignated '''320 Bombardment Squadron''', Heavy on 6 March 1944 : Inactivated on 27 January 1946 * Redesignated '''320 Bombardment Squadron''', Very Heavy on 11 June 1947 : Activated on 1 July 1947 : Inactivated on 6 September 1948 * Redesignated '''320 Bombardment Squadron''', Medium on 20 December 1950 : Activated on 2 January 1951 : Redesignated '''320 Strategic Reconnaissance Squadron''', Medium on 16 June 1952 : Discontinued on 20 June 1960 * Redesignated '''320 Strategic Missile Squadron''' (ICBM-Minuteman) on 30 July 1963 (not organized) : Organized on 8 January 1964 : Redesignated '''320 Missile Squadron''' on 1 September 1991 ===Assignments=== * [[90th Bombardment Group]], 15 April 1942 - 27 January 1946 * 90th Bombardment Group, 1 July 1947 - 6 September 1948 * 90th Bombardment Group, 2 January 1951 (attached to [[90th Bombardment Wing]] after 16 February 1951) * 90th Strategic Reconnaissance Wing, 16 June 1952 - 20 June 1960 * [[Strategic Air Command]], 30 July 1963 (not organized) * 90th Strategic Missile Wing, 8 January 1964 * 90th Operations Group, 1 September 1991 – present ===Stations=== {{div col|2}} * Key Field, Mississippi, 15 April 1942 * [[Barksdale Field]], Louisiana, 17 May 1942 * [[Greenville Army Air Base]], South Carolina, 21 June 1942 * Willow Run Airport, Michigan, 9 - 23 August 1942 * [[Kipapa Airfield]], Hawaii, 12 September 1942 * [[Iron Range Airfield]], Queensland, Australia, c. 4 November 1942 * [[Jacksons International Airport|Jackson Airfield (7 Mile Drome)]], [[Port Moresby]], New Guinea, 10 February 1943 * [[Dobodura Airfield Complex]], New Guinea, December 1943 * [[Nadzab Airfield Complex]], New Guinea, c. 23 February 1944 * [[Mokmer Airfield]], [[Biak Island]], Netherlands East Indies, c. 10 August 1944 * [[San Jose Airport (Mindoro)|McGuire Field]], [[Mindoro]], Philippines, 27 January 1945 * [[Ie Shima Airfield]], [[Okinawa]], 10 August 1945 * [[Fort William McKinley]], [[Luzon]], Philippines, 23 November 1945 - 27 January 1946 * Andrews Field (later Andrews Air Force Base, Maryland, 1 July 1947 - 6 September 1948 * Fairchild Air Force Base, Washington, 2 January 1951 * [[Forbes Air Force Base]], Kansas, 14 March 1951 - 20 June 1960 * [[Francis E. Warren Air Force Base]], Wyoming, 8 January 1964 - present {{div col end}} ===Aircraft and missiles=== {{div col|2}} * [[Consolidated B-24 Liberator]] (1942–1945) * [[Boeing RB-29 Superfortress]] (1951–1954) * [[Boeing RB-47E Stratojet]] (1954–1960) * [[LGM-30B Minuteman I]] (1964–1974) * LGM-30G Minuteman III (1973–present) {{div col end}} ===Awards and campaigns=== {{unit awards table |award_image1=AF PUC |award_name1=[[Distinguished Unit Citation]] |award_date1=c. 4 November 1942–23 January 1943 |award_notes1=Papua, 320th Bombardment Squadron |award_image2=AF PUC |award_name2=Distinguished Unit Citation |award_date2=13 and 15 September 1943 |award_notes2=New Guinea, 320th Bombardment Squadron |award_image3=AF OUA |award_name3=[[Air Force Outstanding Unit Award]] |award_date3=1 July 1968–30 June 1969 |award_notes3=320th Strategic Missile Squadron |award_image4=AF OUA |award_name4=Air Force Outstanding Unit Award |award_date4=1 July 1973–30 June 1975 |award_notes4=320th Strategic Missile Squadron |award_image5=AF OUA |award_name5=Air Force Outstanding Unit Award |award_date5=1 July 1982–30 June 1984 |award_notes5=320th Strategic Missile Squadron |award_image6=AF OUA |award_name6=Air Force Outstanding Unit Award |award_date6=1 July 1986–30 June 1988 |award_notes6=320th Strategic Missile Squadron |award_image7=AF OUA |award_name7=Air Force Outstanding Unit Award |award_date7=1 July 1987–30 June 1989 |award_notes7=320th Strategic Missile Squadron |award_image8=AF OUA |award_name8=Air Force Outstanding Unit Award |award_date8=1 August 1991–31 July 1993 |award_notes8=320th Strategic Missile Squadron
(later 320th Missile Squadron) |award_image9=AF OUA |award_name9=Air Force Outstanding Unit Award |award_date9=1 October 1994–30 September 1995 |award_notes9=320th Missile Squadron |award_image10=AF OUA |award_name10=Air Force Outstanding Unit Award |award_date10=1 September 1996–31 August 1998 |award_notes10=320th Missile Squadron |award_image11=AF OUA |award_name11=Air Force Outstanding Unit Award |award_date11=1 October 1999–30 September 2000 |award_notes11=320th Missile Squadron |award_image12=AF OUA |award_name12=Air Force Outstanding Unit Award |award_date12=1 January 2001–31 December 2001 |award_notes12=320th Missile Squadron |award_image13=AF OUA |award_name13=Air Force Outstanding Unit Award |award_date13=1 October 2003–30 September 2005 |award_notes13=320th Missile Squadron |award_image14=AF OUA |award_name14=Air Force Outstanding Unit Award |award_date14=1 October 2005–30 September 2007 |award_notes14=320th Missile Squadron |award_image15=AF OUA |award_name15=Air Force Outstanding Unit Award |award_date15=1 October 2007–30 September 2008 |award_notes15=320th Missile Squadron |award_image16=PPUC |award_name16=[[Philippine Republic Presidential Unit Citation]] |award_date16=17 October 1944–4 July 1945 |award_notes16=320th Bombardment Squadron }} {| class="wikitable" |- style="background:#efefef;" !
